text: [Music]
Hi, I'm Tim and this is my pronunciation
workshop. Here I'm going to show you how
English is really spoken. Come on, let's
go inside.
[Music]
Just made it a little bit late today. My
alarm didn't go off this morning, so I
nearly missed the bus.
Uh Tim, uh why do you need a bus to get
to the shed at the end of your garden?
Well, you know, it's it's a really big
garden.
Really?
Okay, fine. Look, I'll let you into a
little secret. This actually isn't my
workshop. I've been borrowing it from a
friend. Anyway, um I nearly missed the
bus, but I didn't. So, let's ask some
people in London what they would do if
their alarms hadn't gone off this
morning.
If my alarm hadn't gone off this
morning, I'd have missed the bus. I'd
have stayed home.
I'd have woken up anyway.
I'd have been late for work. I'd have
missed the train.
I'd have stayed in bed.
In an earlier video, we saw that the
verb have is pronounced have when it's
used in its modal form. But this isn't
the only way the pronunciation of have
can change. Watch and listen again. Can
you hear how they pronounce it
differently?
If my alarm hadn't gone off this
morning, I'd have missed the bus. I'd
have stayed home.
I'd have woken up anyway.
I'd have been late for work. I'd have
missed the train.
I'd have stayed in bed. When the verb
have is used as an auxiliary, it's often
contracted. And when it comes after a
consonant sound, it's pronounced.
So, I'd have been late becomes I'd have
been late. Now, this pronunciation is
very common in conditional sentences,
but it's not the only time you'll hear
it. Here are some more examples.
Your parcel should have been delivered
yesterday.
I would have done it differently.
We might have made a mistake.
The police have arrived.
Right. So, you've heard the examples and
now it's your turn. Listen and repeat.
Your parcel should have been delivered
yesterday.
I would have done it differently.
We might have made a mistake.
The police have arrived.
Well done. Now remember, if you want to
learn more about pronunciation, then
please visit our website
bbclearningenglish.com.
And that is about it from the
pronunciation workshop for this week.
I'll see you soon. Bye-bye.
Okay. Now, how does this alarm work?
[Music]
I guess I should have read the
instructions.
That was really loud.
[Music]
